response.answer_text: He was killed by his doctors. The other answers gave some good detail on this, but in short, he had some kind of respiratory ailment (some biographies call it pneumonia, but we don’t know what it really was) and he called for doctors, who administered treatments that finished him off. The “remedies” applied included blistering, cupping, and other things that today would be considered torture. Bloodletting was very likely the actual cause of death. Draining blood out of your veins was supposed to be good for you, and some practitioners figured the more blood removed, the better. If bloodletting didn’t make you well, they suspected it was because you needed to lose more blood. They took several pints out of General Washington over the course of a day or two. The last time alone, they took a quart. Remember that these doctors were not quacks or nut cases by the standards of the time. They were some of the leading physicians around, at least socially, if not scientifically. It seems shocking now, but no doubt some of our ideas about health will horrify people 200 years in the future.
